high school."31 "Second-grade" referred to the length of time for which the license was valid. Any second-grade teaching license, regardless of level, was good for only two years; first-grade licenses were good for five years. The amount of education that the teacher had acquired determined the grade level of the license. Those with thirty-six weeks of training received a second-grade license. Completion of an approved two-year course for any elementary license raised the license to first grade. The initial licensing law in 1923 provided that a life license could be issued to anyone with a first-grade license who had completed three years of successful teaching. The state's attorney general, however, ruled that the life license could be granted only after completion of the five-year period for which the first-grade license was valid.32

In 1927 Lutes renewed his second-grade license. He had by this time acquired an additional twelve hours of credit at Central Normal. By 1929 Lutes had completed two years of course work, and his third license was upgraded to first grade. When this license expired in 1934, Floyd S. McMurray, state superintendent of public instruction, signed Lutes's life license. Along with his marriage and his new job at Allen's Creek, it was cause for celebration. Lutes had acquired an additional ninety-six quarter hours of education between 1929 and 1934. With his life license in hand, he needed no further schooling to continue his career. In 1941, however, Lutes graduated from Indiana University with a B.S. in Education and received his fifth, and last, license-also for life. He had now satisfied the criteria for a regular first-grade high school license in specified subjects: social studies, option II, which was general or United States history; and science, option II, which included biology and physiology. Ironically, the mathematics he liked so well was not included. Lutes was, then, a rural elementary teacher who worked to upgrade and improve his licenses and who continued his education to the end of his career. He was also unusual for his time in that very few of his contemporaries were able to teach from first grade through twelfth grade in any type school.33

A second law that resulted in part from the GEB and Rural Education surveys dealt with teacher tenure. In 1927 the Indiana legislature passed a law that granted teachers who had taught at one school for at least five years a permanent contract. This regulation was an effort to stop the indiscriminate dismissal of teachers
31 Marshall Lutes, Indiana State Teachers' Licenses, Lutes Collection.
32 Indiana Department of Public Instruction, Annual Report of the Department of Public Instruction of the State of Indiana., 1925–1926 ([ Indianapolis ], 1926), 106–107.
33 Lutes, Reminiscences; Lutes, Licenses. See below for a discussion of Lutes's acquisition of his M.S. in Education. Although Lutes could have taught specified subjects at the high school level, he continued to teach in elementary schools in or near rural areas, schools in which he found "bright" students who, he insisted, deserved the best education that he could provide regardless of circumstances.
for various reasons, one of which was to avoid paying higher salaries to more experienced teachers. Unfortunately, the teacher tenure law was repealed for rural township schools in 1933 because of the effects of the Great Depression.34 Exactly how this law affected Lutes is uncertain. He changed schools fairly frequently, never remaining at the same location for more than three consecutive years. He taught at Allen's Creek for three years; at Harrodsburg and Hunter's Creek for two years each, at the latter on two separate occasions; and at Elkinsville and White's for one year each. In only one instance is the reason for his departure from these schools stated explicitly. In 1934 the township trustee at Harrodsburg in Monroe County indicated his intention to hire "Home tallant" rather than an "outsider" from Jackson County . Since trustees frequently hired relatives, friends, and local residents in preference to teachers from other localities, the incident at Harrodsburg was not unique. Trustees often fired teachers for political reasons as well. Lutes, however, was a Democrat who for the first ten years of his career taught in the heavily Democratic areas of Jackson, Brown , and southern Monroe counties . He could have been dismissed for purely political reasons, but it seems unlikely. Personal animosities are also possible causes for dismissal, as was the accepted, though unwritten, rule throughout the Midwest that teachers be employed for only one term or at most for two. Lutes, like a number of his contemporaries, may have chosen to change schools in an effort to improve his salary or working conditions.35 His move to Washington Consolidated elementary school in 1937 would certainly have been a case in point. Unfortunately, Lutes's reminiscences reveal little about his moves from one school to another; evidently "getting fired" was a painful subject regardless of the reasons. At any rate, Lutes was never granted tenure until he taught for a city school corporation much later in his career.36

The 1920s and 1930s also saw informed legislators and interested citizens push for reform in school financing, particularly equalization of school taxes and increased state support. During these decades most of the revenue burden for schools was borne by the general property tax. In the 1920s around 95 percent of all school moneys came from local property taxes; the remaining 5 percent resulted from state support. The Great Depression of the 1930s significantly affected teachers and the school system as a whole. Many received lower or deferred salaries or had to "make do" with short-term appointments. A few of the less fortunate lost their jobs altogether, and the remainder struggled with larger student-teacher ratios. The depression's
34 Indiana, Laws (1927), 259–62; Indiana, Laws (1933), 716–19; Madison , Indiana through Tradition and Change, 275–76, 283.
35 Lutes, Reminiscences; Fuller, The Old Country School, 216–17.
36 Lutes, Reminiscences. See below for further discussion of township trustees and their administration of rural schools.
greatest effect, however, was the shift to increased state funding. By 1933 the state was providing a 30 percent share of the local school revenue, an increase made possible in part by the gross income tax instituted by Governor Paul V. McNutt.37 Although eventually increased state support would mean increased state control of local schools, many recognized the necessity for the change. A recurrent theme in Lutes's reminiscences is his contention that teachers as a group were relatively well off during the depression. People could do without the services provided by other occupations, Lutes often said, but unless state laws were changed, kids had to be taught. His salary might be lower, but at least he had a salary. He was better off during the depression, he claimed, than he had ever been before. Despite the obvious discrepancies in his reasoning and despite the fact that after one school term he and other teachers had to sue the township trustee for their salaries (they eventually received a portion of what was due them), Lutes's point was particularly valid for him. He bought and paid for a twenty-acre homeplace during the depression years, something he could never have done earlier and that would have been difficult even in later years. In general, historians agree with Lutes's assessment. Teachers' salaries throughout the United States dropped drastically between 1929 and 1934, but they dropped "far less than … [those] of ministers or engineers. … In fact, teachers were better off in comparison with most other workers in 1933–34 than they have ever been since."38

During the period 1920–1940-and indeed for many years before and after-township trustees controlled rural elementary education in Indiana. For at least half of his long career Lutes taught under the trustee system, which had been initiated in 1852. Trustees, whose major duties were to supervise the local schools and disburse welfare in the township, were elected to a four-year term on a party ballot. Under their jurisdiction were the several small township schools that served each community. Trustees were in charge of hiring and firing teachers, all school finances (supplies, budget, tax levies), school buildings, and all school property.39

Any survey, study, discussion, or recommendation concerning rural education sooner or later focused on the township trustee, who possessed "almost autocratic power over the schools."40 Trustees generally had little, if any, professional education; rather, they were the products of a common school background. Further, they were many times elected not because of their interest in education but because
37 Report of the Indiana Rural Education Survey Committee, 60; Madison , Indiana through Tradition and Change, 283.
38 Lutes, Reminiscences; Tyack, Lowe, and Hansot, Public Schools in Hard Times, chaps. 1–4, quotation 39.
39 GEB Survey, 134; Report of the Indiana Rural Education Survey Committee, 51.
40 GEB Survey, 134.
of their ability to handle the political parties' interests. According to the GEB survey, trustees were therefore not prepared to make good decisions, hiring and firing teachers and purchasing supplies on the basis of personal or partisan desires. Indeed, the commission found the entire system inefficient and financially extravagant, and the survey concluded: "personal bias, political ambition, favoritism, and inefficiency will continue, in most counties, to rule the rural school so long as township trustees are in control."41

In 1926 the survey of the Rural Education Commission in Indiana confirmed the GEB findings. Of the teachers questioned 85 percent had moved mom one school position to another because of the personal whims of the trustees or because of their political party affiliations. Gwen Hays, for example, had to move from a larger school to a small, one-room rural school because "my politics wasn't quite the same as the Trustee's was." Such an occurrence, Hays indicated, was not unusual.42 In 1934 the Monroe County study was still listing political affiliation and personal wish of trustee as the number one and number two reasons for teachers to change positions.43 The Hoosier state was not unique; teachers throughout the country corroborated the Indiana experience. In Kansas one educator warned his readers to look with suspicion on any teacher who said he bossed the trustee or the local community school board, for "he is either a liar or a onetermer and the probabilities are that he is both."44 Present-day historians have continued to blast the trustee system in Indiana and elsewhere. A trustee's decisions in locating and building schools and in purchasing only the basic supplies often reflected his "politically partisan and local orientation and sometimes his own economic selfinterest as well." Further, trustees frequently used their power to appoint and dismiss teachers "to reward friends and punish enemies, whether personal or political."45

As indicated earlier, Lutes, too, ran afoul of the trustee system on occasion. For example, the Clear Creek Township ( Monroe County ) trustee wrote Lutes a recommendation after dismissing him from Harrodsburg in 1934.

42 Hays interview; Report of the Indiana Rural Education Survey Committee, 46.

43
Monroe County study, 38. Statistics attesting to teachers' dismissals because of township trustees' personal or political whims should, of course, be used cautiously. While undoubtedly true in a large majority of cases, teachers were far more likely to attribute their departure from a school to reasons other than their own inadequacies. Further, virtually every early twentieth-century teacher's reminiscence, journal, or oral interview recounts at least one dismissal by the township trustee for political reasons. That the practice was widespread is certain; that it became a matter of considerable pride for teachers to claim the experience equally so.
44 Quoted in Tyack, The One Best System, 18.

div.p:
To Whom May Concern
Marshall Lutes taught School two School yr in Clear Creek twp.
Was Honest truthful to all who come in contact with Him. Was a High quailfy teacher. School was Raited 1 an 2 by state Department good on Diciplin I can say there be No Mistake by Hiring Him why I Did Not Retain Him Was Home tallant Will Never Bother about pay
[signature] trustee46
Despite Lutes's good professional and moral standards, the trustee preferred to hire someone from the immediate area, probably someone he knew.47 It is also interesting to note that the trustee considered Lutes's disinclination to create problems over his salary as a positive recommendation.

From 1937 to 1948 Lutes taught at Washington Township Consolidated, a four-room school in northern Monroe County . This portion of the county differed significantly from the southern part. The residents' ancestors were of southern nativity as they had been at Allen's Creek and Hunter's Creek; but many of them had originated in a different area of the South, and they had arrived in southern Indiana and Monroe County by different routes. In Washington Township the majority of voters were Republicans; the people were relatively more affluent; and they were for the most part better educated. For Lutes to obtain a position at Washington Consolidated, particularly a principalship, was a definite "step up" in his career. The township trustee, however, was still the dominant figure in the educational system. At Consolidated, as the community termed it, Lutes was hired by a Republican who knew that he was a Democrat; he then taught for a Republican who suspected that he was a Democrat but did not know for sure; still later he taught for a Democratic trustee; and finally he was fired by a Republican. Lutes was never certain whether he was fired because of his political affiliation or because of personal differences with a few of the more influential men in the community (all Republicans to be sure).48

Obviously, Lutes recognized the problems inherent in the township trustee system, yet he never denigrated the system as such. Like many of the patrons of his schools he felt that local communities should retain as much control as possible over the education of their children, and he looked askance at being "dictated to" by people "up in Indianapolis " who did not understand local conditions. Most of the trustees under whom Lutes worked he characterized as good, decent, caring individuals who wanted the best education possible
46 Marshall Lutes, Letters of Recommendation, Lutes Collection. The trustee's name has been withheld.
47 In his reminiscences Lutes claimed that he was replaced by the trustee's niece.
48 Lutes, Reminiscences; Monroe County study, 25–30.
for the children in their community. If they had no formal educational training, they were honest, and in a sense they were astute businessmen as well. They did the best they could with usually meager funds, Lutes averred, and most of them left "teaching to the teachers," to his mind the ultimate accolade.49

In recent years a number of well-known historians have agreed with much of Lutes's assessment of the township trustee. "It was easy," one of them writes, "to pass such men off as country bumpkins, and, unfortunately, the numerous complaints lodged against them through the years drew a portrait of miserly, apathetic, uneducated educators leading their little schools into educational bankruptcy." However, the author continues, "The most that can be known about the midwestern country-school directors is to be found in the accounts of'their doings,' as their book of records called them, and these, considered as a whole, show them to have been conscientious, earnest men, who tried to improve their schools and who displayed a considerable amount of common sense and business ability in managing their schools' affairs."50 Other critics recognized that all governmental school administrators, not merely the township trustees, were inclined to be too partisan and involved in politics. Even at the state level, according to these historians, there was a "lack of stability" that affected the entire educational system. Lutes agreed. A victim of the trustee system on more than one occasion, he had also struggled under the dictates of a state-controlled bureaucracy.51

County superintendents also received their share of the critics' attention during the 1920s and 1930s. Elected for a four-year term by all township trustees in a county, superintendents, too, were enmeshed in local partisan political struggles. State requirements for the office, which had been created in 1873, included a college degree and teaching experience. Few counties, however, adhered to these regulations, party affiliation being the paramount criterion for election. The position was considered a weak one, with the superintendent often seen as the trustees' errand boy. In actual fact, a strong superintendent could often exert considerable influence over both the trustees and the local schools. Technically, the superintendent's duties included serving as a go-between for the trustees and the state superintendent of public instruction, collecting and forwarding to the state various statistics on the county schools, and supervising and grading all teachers in the county. The trustees hired the teachers, but it was the superintendent who evaluated them, usually in twiceyearly visits of approximately eighty minutes each.52

50 Fuller, The Old Country School, 85.

div.p: Superintendents used a success schedule, or standardized checklist, to rate teachers and to assign them a grade. Evaluation categories included: personality, 15 points; preparation, 15 points; teaching technique, 20; pupil achievement, 20; management, 10; cooperation and professional attitude, 15; and professional reading, 5. A score of 95 and above was excellent; 90–94, good; 85–89, average; 80–84, poor; and 79 and below, failure. Grades were to be assigned according to a normal distribution, meaning that the majority of teachers should fall in the 85–89, or average, category. These "success grades" were used for salary negotiations, for recommendations, for teacher knowledge, and for renewing or converting licenses. Teachers had to have all success grades at 80 or above for license renewal. The 1925 Rural Education survey reported that the majority of one-room rural teachers had ratings in the 90–94, or good, range. Not surprisingly, the county superintendents did not agree with the committee's assessment of "inadequate" instruction in the one-room rural schools.53

Lutes makes no reference to his relationship with the county superintendents in Jackson or Brown counties . In Monroe County , particularly during the 1930s, he conferred often with the superintendents in order to keep them, as well as the trustees, abreast of conditions in his school. Lutes was rated "average" for his first two teaching years-at White's and Hunter's Creek. At Elkinsville (1929–1930) and during his second stint at Hunter's Creek (1930–1931), he scored a 94-the top end of the "good" category. From 1931 on, his success grade was "excellent," ranging from 95 to 98. Lutes almost always received high marks in personality and professional attitude, teaching technique, and management. He rated lowest in "professional reading," something, as the Monroe County study confirmed, that might have been expected from a teacher on a minimum salary who covered all subjects across eight grades in isolated, deeply rural schools with virtually no access to library facilities.54

Although, as previously indicated, consolidation was fought longer and harder than other reforms suggested by the GEB, Rural Education, and similar surveys, the period from 1920 to 1940 was the beginning of the end for the rural one-room schools. Many reformers who pushed for consolidation lobbied for a county-unit system, with a county board to replace the township trustees. The advantages of this type organization included more centralized purchasing of school supplies, more efficient use of teachers, more uniform and fairer tax rates, and more uniform quality throughout the schools. Because of the extremely stiff opposition to consolidation in the local communities,
53 Report of the Indiana Rural Education Survey Committee, 118–21, 36, 50.
54 Marshall Lutes, Success Schedules, Lutes Collection; Lutes, Reminiscences; Monroe County study, 43–45.
school reformers began to work at the state level. During the decades of the 1920s and 1930s most superintendents of public instruction favored the county-unit plan. In 1923 the state Senate debated but failed to pass legislation that would mandate schools to reorganize along county lines. In 1924 the Department of Public Instruction, with funds provided by the Greneral Education Board, established in Johnson and LaGrange counties an experimental countywide purchasing, accounting, and teacher supervision project. The experiment was deemed successful by some in improving teaching and learning in the two model counties; the financial feature of the model program was considered a failure, primarily because the township trustees refused to cooperate. Overall the project convinced only those who wanted to believe. In 1925 the state legislature soundly defeated a second county-unit bill.55

Residents of small rural communities throughout the United States opposed consolidation out of much more than ignorance and self-interest. They feared it. True, centralization might mean higher taxes, which they did not want, but it would also mean new policies and programs that they thought alien to their way of life. These they did not want either. The school, along with the church, was a source of local pride, the focus of the community, and most local citizensnot merely the township trustees-did not want to relinquish control. The consolidation movement, they felt, threatened to destroy the institution that held the rural areas together.56 Many reformers who attacked the "bookish" curriculum, haphazard selection and supervision of teachers, erratic school attendance, discipline, diversity of buildings, and lack of equipment recognized these problems as merely symptoms of what was wrong with rural school education. More basic, they averred, was the fact that rural residents wanted to run their own schools and that they did not know what was good for them in the complex new society. Antagonists in the conflict also realized that basic community and societal values were at stake. As one angry rural schoolteacher in Oregon stated, "The paradox of American Education is that it asks for education for all, yet urges that control of the educational system be placed in a bureaucracy," as if local citizens could not be trusted to manage their own schools.57 One small-town newspaper editor in Indiana rather graphically expressed the opinion of many country dwellers on consolidation:
55
Madison , "John D. Rockefeller's General Education Board," 185–87, 189, 192; Madison , Indiana through Tradition and Change, 271–74; Indiana, Senate Journal (1923), 721; Indiana, Senate Journal (1925), 271–72, 525.
56
Madison , Indiana through Tradition and Change, 265, 272; Madison , "John D. Rockefeller's General Education Board," 193–94; Fuller, The Old Country School, 234–35.
57 Tyack, The One Best System, 21–24, quotation 24.
Now comes [sic] the theorists and reformers, led by the well paid experts from the East and the self-appointed prophets from the state university [Indiana University] and Purdue, ably re-enforced by the school book drafters and cheered on by the politicians with a mania for centralization. …The taxpayer has his belly full of centralized government. The trustees are particularly precious, for they represent the last vestige of the fading right of the voter to have a personal hand in the management of local affairs.58

Despite such strong opposition consolidation was inevitable. It came slowly in Indiana, primarily within townships at first, and it was done with local approval, not solely by state mandate. Trustees retained their existence and most of their power. Between 1920 and 1940 the number of one-room schools in the Hoosier state was reduced by over one-half. There were 4,500 schools in 1920, and by 1945 only 616 remained. What professional educators, school reformers, and politicians had not been able to do, increasing technology in the form of better communication and transportation (blacktopped roads, for example) had accomplished.59 In the end some rejoiced and some mourned for the loss of the ideals of the old one-room common school.

In 1937 Lutes began his eleven-year stint at Washington Consolidated, one of the small consolidations within a single township. The building was frame, with four classrooms, a small workroom, and a partial basement. Other than its size Consolidated closely resembled Lutes's one-room schools.60 Drinking water was still carried in from a well in the schoolyard; privies were still outside; lunches were still brought from home; and playground equipment was minimal. There was a janitor, however, who fired the furnace in the basement and who was supposed to sweep the floors and wash the blackboards. There were also state-approved "free" textbooks and three teachers in addition to Lutes. None of the four had a four-year degree. Two, including Lutes (in 1941), later acquired a bachelor's degree in education; one continued to teach for many years with only eighteen weeks (one semester) of training.61 During Lutes's tenure at Consolidated, but probably not by 1940, the school nurse for the
58 Quoted in James H. Madison, The Indiana Way: A State History ( Bloomington , 1986), 249.
59
Madison , Indiana through Tradition and Change, 274; Swanson, Rural One-Room Schools of Mid-America, 29–31; Fuller, The Old Country School, 244–45; Barnhart and Carmony, Indiana, II, 508. The last one-room school in Indiana was Chapel Hill in Polk Township in Monroe County . It closed in 1967 amid many of the same arguments that opponents of consolidation had propounded in the 1920s and 1930s.
60 Lutes, Reminiscences; Monroe County study, 48.
61 On a number of occasions Lutes suggested that the township trustees consider replacing this teacher with one who had more training. Although the trustees all agreed that the situation, in a professional sense, was unsatisfactory, they apparently could find no one else who was willing to come to the rural school. Further, the teacher was very popular in the community. Lutes was extremely proud that free textbooks were available for all students at Consolidated, something that had not been and would not be the case in his other rural schools. One entire day at the end of each year he set aside for students to erase marks in and mend books for the next year's use. Lutes, Reminiscences.
WASHINGTON CONSOLIDATED
county and the county library truck, made periodic-though infrequent-visits to the school. As principal, Lutes, among many other duties, supervised all teachers, dealt with the township trustee and county superintendent, taught both the seventh and eighth grades, and organized special events. Box suppers and pie socials raised money for "extras" such as reference books or balls and bats; the annual Christmas play was attended by the entire township; and the eighth grade graduation ceremony was a larger and even more important occasion than it had been in the smaller, one-room schools. For some students this ceremony signaled the end of formal education; the rest would attend the high school in Bloomington for at least a few years.62

After Lutes left Washington Consolidated in 1948, he moved to Hensonburg School, another township consolidation on the outskirts of Bloomington . The building was a two-story, four-room brick structure, but again little else was different. The school was administered by a township trustee; there was no water inside the building, thus no bathroom facilities; there was no school lunch program; and for the first few years there were no free textbooks. Situated just outside one of Bloomington 's poorest districts, Hensonburg was labeled a "tough" school, but Lutes evidently felt at home there. He remained as principal and head teacher for twenty-one years. By the early 1950s virtually all one-room schools in Indiana were gone, and even the small four- and six-room consolidations were being closed, their students transferred to schools in the growing towns and cities. Hensonburg continued to exist as a rural township school until 1953 when it was absorbed into the Bloomington Metropolitan School Corporation, administered by a superintendent and school board. Lutes had finally made the transition to the city schools, with their higher salaries, improved school conditions, and tenure. While at Hensonburg-as indeed he had while at Consolidated-Lutes supplemented his salary, as most male teachers who were heads of families had to do, by working at the local soft-drink bottling companies during the summer months. It was a seasonal arrangement that benefited both employer and employee. He also continued his education. At the age of fifty-eight Lutes obtained his master's degree in education from Indiana University, often taking classes with his son and son-in-law who were working toward the same goal.63

In 1969, one year before Lutes's mandatory retirement at the age of sixty-seven, Hensonburg was closed. Its students were disbursed
62 Lutes, Reminiscences. In 1940 Lutes scheduled the Unionville High School orchestra from a neighboring township to play at Commencement, had the county superintendent deliver the address, and asked one of the local ministers to give the invocation and benediction. There were even mimeographed programs, in three colors, for the audience and participants, and Lutes himself presented the diplomas to the fourteen graduates.
63 Lutes, Reminiscences.
to various other elementary schools within Bloomington . Lutes was asked to teach his final year at the Arlington Elementary School and to test a new concept. Fearful at first, he agreed when told that the administration wanted to place two grades-the fifth and sixth-in one room to see what benefits or problems, if any, might occur. Lutes told his daughter, with a grin, that he thought he "could handle that."64 Another teacher who wrote of the changes in education over time would have shared the humor in the situation: "It was inevitable that, as society urbanized, the educational system would be caught in the throes of consolidation, unification, desegregation, and all the other 'tions' that designate the development of mass education. It was also inevitable such developments would necessitate change, growth, and innovation in the educative process"; but, the author points out, many, if not most, of the innovations and ideas that are considered "new age," such as flexible scheduling, open classrooms, individualized instruction, cooperative learning, and parent-teacherpupil interaction are just the old ideas started in the one-room schools.65

Lutes retired in 1970 after forty-four years in the teaching profession. His early career, from 1920 to 1940, was both consistent with and divergent from the norm as revealed in the GEB study and the 1925 survey. Lutes taught in one-room schools for ten years-longer than most of his contemporaries. He remained in rural consolidated schools for even more years before his employment by a large city school corporation in 1953. He had more formal training than many of his colleagues in the rural schools. The small, rural, district schools that emerge from his reminiscences are, however, archetypes of those throughout the Midwest in the 1920s, 1930s, and beyond. Often unwilling participants in the reform fervor that swept Indiana and the nation in the early decades of the twentieth century, these schools changed little between 1920 and 1940. Not until after World War II, in fact, did any significant modifications occur, and even then they came slowly. Lutes was, of course, aware of the changes that affected the schools and communities in which he taught. Many of them he welcomed; many he did not. Had he and his contemporaries been asked to assess their careers during the 1920s and 1930s, most would have agreed that there were good times and bad times during these decades; but "if there was pain as well as joy in their one-room schools, so was there in life itself."66

div.head: INDIANA ARCHIVES Archival Holdings in Northern Indiana

byline.hi: John M. Glen, Patrick J. Furlong, and Elizabeth A. Krehbiel-Kutzko

div.p: The Indiana Archives section of the Indiana Magazine of History turns its attention this year to local archival holdings in the northern part of Indiana. Defining northern Indiana is admittedly an impressionistic enterprise, easily subject to debate. Its boundaries are largely a matter of ascertaining identity; that is, how a city or county orients itself toward the rest of the state and toward areas outside Indiana's borders. After careful consideration, and acknowledging that the Calumet Region of northwest Indiana claims its own particular identity, "northern Indiana" in this article is geographically outlined as the region extending northward from a line roughly going through Logansport, Wabash, Huntington , and Decatur ; the region, in other words, lying east of La Porte , Starke, Pulaski , and White counties .

The history and culture of northern Indiana offer more helpful ways of distinguishing it from other parts of the state. The names of its towns, rivers, and lakes are reminders that the original inhabitants were several Native American tribes of the Great Lakes region, particularly the Potawatomi and Miami. It was the first part of Indiana to be seen by European explorers and missionaries, yet, with the exception of Fort Wayne , it was the last part of the state to be opened to European settlement. Large numbers of these migrants came from the East- New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio , New England , and, after the Revolution of 1848, Germany and Poland -rather than from the South as was the case in southern Indiana. Their descendants, along with the Eastern European immigrants who arrived in the twentieth century and the Amish communities still sprinkled across the region, have led some writers to suggest that in demographic terms northern Indianians have blurred and modified the usual conceptions of Hoosierdom.

Northern Indiana's distinctiveness also stems in part from its particular ties to industry, education, and some of the state's most
* John M. Glen, general editor of the Indiana Archives series, is professor of history, Ball State University, Muncie , Indiana. Contributors to this installment of the series are Patrick J. Furlong, professor of history, Indiana University South Bend , and Elizabeth A. Krehbiel-Kutzko, assistant director, Elkhart County Historical Museum, Elkhart , Indiana.
notable public figures. It was an early center of the automobile industry: the region's museums commemorate models such as Duesenberg and Studebaker. Large amounts of durable manufactured goods continue to pour out of its factories, from automobile parts to household appliances to recreational vehicles. Its most prominent place of higher education is the University of Notre Dame, whose football prowess and academic agenda, the latter cultivated during the administration of Father Theodore Hesburgh, make it as much a national institution as a college in Indiana. Northern Indiana also has been home to Thomas R. Marshall, Progressive Era governor and Woodrow Wilson's vice-president; early twentieth-century writer and naturalist Gene Stratton Porter, who used the wilderness around her Limberlost cabin as a background for her novels and studies; Jesse Lee Dickinson, who worked to end racial discrimination in education, employment, and public facilities while representing St. Joseph County in the General Assembly during the 1940s and 1950s; Democratic congressman John Brademas, who sought to improve the financing of higher education in the 1960s and 1970s; and Republican Otis R. "Doc" Bowen, longtime state legislator, two-term governor, and Secretary of Health and Human Services during the Ronald Reagan presidency, who brought the state into a closer working relationship with the federal government.

In short, beyond its popular reputation as "lake country," where thousands of vacationers congregate every summer, or "Michiana," where residents share a close affinity with southern Michigan , northern Indiana possesses an independent historical identity worthy of further study, as this year's contributors make clear. Patrick J. Furlong offers a useful panoramic overview of the kinds of sources available at university, college, church-related, museum, county, and historical society archives throughout the region. Complementing this survey is Elizabeth A. Krehbiel-Kutzko's description of the archival holdings of the Elkhart County Historical Museum, a discussion that reflects the energetic restructuring of the museum's curatorial facilities and accession lists as well as the revamping of its organizational strategies. Their essays are reminders that establishing local and regional identities, even within the boundaries of a single state, is almost always a work in progress.

Many institutions in the northern part of Indiana have archival and manuscript holdings, but few of them can afford trained archivists. As a result, their holdings are often not systematically arranged and cataloged, and finding aids are few. At local historical societies the archival collections are often managed by volunteers who can work only a few hours a week. Researchers therefore should call ahead and be prepared to explain clearly what sorts of information they are seeking.

St. Joseph County has one of a very few formally established archives among Indiana's ninety-two counties. It holds virtually all noncurrent county records except deeds, easements, and other land records, which remain at the county recorder's office. Criminal, civil, and probate court records are located in the archives, as well as the minutes books of the county commissioners and the county council, the county coroner's files, and most other departmental files. The county archives also have the noncurrent records of the city of South Bend from its incorporation in 1865 and the few surviving records of the town of South Bend . Very few township records have been preserved, and only Union Township records dating from the early years of the twentieth century have been placed in the county archives. Except for juvenile court and paternity case files after 1941, almost all records are open for research.

The special collections of the Hesburgh Library at the University of Notre Dame are wide ranging in time and distance, and this essay reviews only those likely to interest researchers in Indiana and midwestern history. There is, of course, an extensive collection of Notre Dame materials, as well as the Catholic Americana Collection of parish histories and religious pamphlets, the Modern Manuscripts Collection, and the Modern Authors Collection. Two other groups deserve particular attention. First, there is an extensive collection of items relating to Catholic missionaries to the Indians of the southern Great Lakes region, primarily the Potawatomi and Ojibwa (Chippewa), in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. Second, the richest portion of the Joyce Sports Research Collection concerns college football, but there are extensive holdings for professional football and boxing, as well as for college basketball and baseball. There are annual guides and yearbooks dating from 1891 to the present, more than twenty thousand college and professional football game programs, and coaching notebooks from the early twentieth century. The papers of sportswriter Rowland P. "Red" Smith offer a close-up view of American sports for the middle years of the twentieth century. A detailed list of the archives' holdings can be found at its World Wide Web site: http:/www.nd.edu/~rarebook/Dept/ Text /collections.html.

The Otis Bowen Library at Bethel College in Mishawaka holds a large collection of Bowen's personal papers covering his many years of public service in the Indiana General Assembly, as governor from 1973 to 1981, and as Secretary of Health and Human Services from 1985 to 1989. The collection is most extensive for his eight years as governor. Bethel College also holds the Missionary Church Archives and Historical Collection that traces the growth of the Missionary Church from its Amish, Mennonite, and River Brethren traditions. Although the earliest documents are from the 1820s, the bulk of the collection dates from the 1860s.

At regional campuses, Indiana University-Purdue University Fort Wayne holds the portion of the Sylvia Bowman Papers that covers
her editorial work for the Twayne Authors Series, which published more than fifty biographies of well-known British and American writers. Indiana University South Bend holds audio tapes and typed transcripts of radio broadcasts by Clarence E. Manion, a conservative political commentator whose Manion Forum was broadcast from 1954 to 1979. There are some tapes from 1954–1955 and a virtually complete collection from 1961 to 1979, more than three hundred altogether. Complementing the tapes is a complete file of typed transcripts for the years 1955–1961, as well as a file of the Manion Forum newsletter for 1961–1978.

Religious bodies often have valuable archival collections, although many of them are not professionally cataloged. The Congregation of Holy Cross, the religious order that founded and still directs the University of Notre Dame, has its own Indiana Province Archives adjacent to the Notre Dame campus. The Congregational Archives of the Sisters of the Holy Cross are located at Saint Mary's College in Notre Dame and are kept separately from the college library and archives.

The Archives of the Church of the United Brethren in Christ are found at the Huntington College Library. Though some records date from 1800, most of the collection dates from the establishment of the church as a distinct denomination in 1889.

The Church of the Brethren Archives are located at Manchester College in North Manchester and include records of predecessor churches such as the German Baptists, the Grace Baptist Brethren, and Dunkard Brethren. Manchester College also holds the papers of Otho Winger, the institution's longtime president and a historian who wrote extensively about the Miami and Potawatomi of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. The Lemberg Collection documents some of the violent aspects of the civil rights movement of the 1960s and 1970s. The papers of Mt. Morris College of Mt. Morris, Illinois , which closed in 1932, are also located at Manchester College.

The archives of the Mennonite Church are located at Goshen College, although not as part of the college library. This is a large collection of material on church organizations and activities throughout North America, including Mennonite General Conference records from 1898, Mission Board Records from 1882, educational records from 1894, and publishing records from 1906. The collection possesses records from twenty-seven Mennonite conferences and more than six hundred congregations. There are also the personal papers of a number of Mennonite ministers, most notably John F. Funk, who published the Herald of Truth in Elkhart from 1884 until 1906.

The Morgan Library at Grace College and Seminary in Winona Lake holds the Winona Lake Historical Collection documenting chautauqua-like meetings, as well as the papers of Billy Sunday, the famed evangelist.

The Catholic Diocese of Fort Wayne - South Bend has a centralized archives at the Chancery Office in Fort Wayne containing parish
and diocesan records from 1857, but the collection is not yet systematically organized for research.

The Northern Indiana Historical Society in South Bend has a small but distinguished collection. The Colfax Family Papers include letters from Schuyler Colfax concerning his service as congressman and speaker of the House, as well as letters from Evelyn Clark Colfax, Ellen Wade Colfax, and Hannah Matthews, which offer three women's perspectives of politics and society in mid-nineteenthcentury Washington . There are also some early business ledgers, notably those detailing the store and fur-trading activities of Lathrop M. Taylor in South Bend , and extensive map and photographic collections. The Northern Indiana Historical Society is also unusually rich in twentieth-century materials. It holds the records of the All-American Girls' Professional Baseball League (1943–1951); a large collection of newsfilm from WSBT-TV in South Bend (1965–1978); the Palmer Slide Collection of local scenes, primarily of the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s; some fifty oral history interviews of area residents; and a collection of construction plans for public buildings in St. Joseph County .

The Louis A. Warren Lincoln Library and Museum in Fort Wayne has accessioned some three hundred documents signed by Abraham Lincoln, as well as a large vertical file of clippings, photographs, and ephemera relating to Lincoln , including a few manuscript items. The library also holds a number of letters and diaries of Civil War soldiers, including those of George Squier of Fort Wayne . The personal papers of three former library directors-Louis A. Warren, R. Gerald McMurtry, and Mark A. Neely-are also available for research.

There are no business archives open for research in northern Indiana, but there are two extensive collections that document automobile and other manufacturing by firms no longer in business. The Studebaker-Packard Archives at the Studebaker National Museum include a vast collection of Studebaker records dating from the wagonand carriage-building efforts of the Studebaker brothers in 1854 to the closing of the South Bend plant of the Studebaker Corporation in 1963. The Studebaker Collection is rich in photographs of wagons, automobiles, and factories and in advertising and other visual material. There is a complete file of the minutes of the corporation's directors and incomplete correspondence files of corporate officers. There are extensive automobile manufacturing records for the period 1946–1963 and a limited number of records concerning automotive design. The records of the Packard Motor Car Company are also incomplete, but their scope extends from the company's beginnings in 1899 to its merger with Studebaker in 1956.

The Studebaker-Packard Archives also have extensive holdings of the records of the Oliver Chilled Plow Company and its successor firms. Included are many glass-plate negatives showing a variety of
plow designs and manufacturing techniques. The records of the recently closed O'Brien Paint Company have not yet been cataloged. Audio tapes and transcripts of interviews by the Michiana Oral Labor History Project document union formation efforts at local plants during the 1930s and 1940s, especially those of United Auto Workers Local 5 at Studebaker and Local 9 at Bendix, including the Bendix sitdown strike of 1936.

The Tri Kappa Collection of Automotive Literature at the AuburnCord-Duesenberg Museum in Auburn focuses primarily on the Auburn Automotive Company, Deusenberg, Inc., and the Cord Corporation and E. L. Cord personally, but there is significant material about other Indiana-built automobiles. The collection is rich in illustrated material, including advertising and owner's manuals.

The Cass County Historical Society in Logansport has the Williamson Wright Family Collection, encompassing the varied activities of a family involved in town development, politics, and railroads. The Harrington Photo Negative Collection shows Logansport scenes and people as recorded by a local studio from the 1890s until 1960. The Henry Tucker Diaries cover the business of Wall and Tucker Undertakers at the turn of the century, while the John W. Coast journal documents the work of a druggist in Young America, Cass County , from the early 1880s until the early 1900s.

p.hi: Archival Materials at the Elkhart County Historical Society

div.p: The Elkhart County Historical Museum houses the collections of the Elkhart County Historical Society. This society is devoted to the preservation and exhibition of artifacts, documents, and photographs dealing with the history of this county, its government, and its people. The organization has been collecting items of historical significance since its founding in 1896, although these collections have only been exhibited and housed within Rush Memorial Center since 1968. The primary focus of the facility today is education and research.

The archives were originally created to hold volumes and papers discarded by Elkhart County governmental offices. The founders also recognized the importance of preserving personal documents regarding the county's early history. Some written correspondence was obtained in the late 1800s, but the bulk of the personal and business materials and photographic images has been donated in more recent years by private individuals who currently live in the county or who had connections in the county at one time.

The potential research opportunities to be found in the archives are numerous and virtually untapped by academics and professionals. Very little has been published regarding Elkhart County 's history and its relationship to the state since the turn of the century. The temporal span of the collections extends from the inception of the
county in 1830 to the present. A surname and business index has been compiled for local government documents from 1830 to 1860. Personal and business papers have been topically indexed. Current endeavors include further indexing of the entire collection and the computerization of these indices to provide easier access for researchers.

Accounts of daily life in nineteenth-century Elkhart County are available in numerous diaries and letters, such as those of the Hively family, John Schwin, and John Nusbaum. Joseph and Silas Hively grew up on a farm south of Elkhart in the 1860s. Silas later owned Hively Grocery on Middlebury Street in Elkhart during the Depression. The diaries of John Schwin and John Nusbaum of Middlebury include descriptions of family life and events on the farm and remarks about the weather. The diaries of J. D. Umberhower and the reflections of Marjorie Harris Smith, a Hively descendant, are twentiethcentury accounts of an increasingly urbanizing local society. Umberhower was an exceptionally active individual who kept a detailed record of his life in Goshen from 1898 to 1911. His activities included playing cello, attending musical events, going to various churches and revivals, visiting children, and renting properties. Smith's personal papers discuss her memories of family life and community activities as she was growing up in Elkhart in the 1920s and 1930s.

Civil War materials at the society are numerous and include both personal documents and government papers. Soldiers' diaries and letters are a valuable source of information. For example, the letters of George B. Dausman, who served in Company H of the 75th Regiment, Indiana Volunteers, contain vivid descriptions of his experiences on the march and in an army hospital in
Murfreesboro, Tennessee . Along with Dausman's correspondence are letters written by family members regarding his illness and by his commanding officers explaining the circumstances of his death on February 28,1863. Other Civil War sources of particular note are the diaries and papers of Captain E. L. Billings, a member of Company K of the 57th Regiment, Indiana Volunteers, and Companies I and D of the 2nd Regiment (Convalescent Camp); the diary of Sergeant Rueben R. Lutz, who served in Company G of the 74th Regiment, Indiana Volunteers; and the diary and papers, including muster roll, of John D. Myers of Company D of the 74th Regiment, Indiana Volunteers. County records also document support payments to the families of the men who were away serving their country; muster rolls, including that of the Goshen Invincibles, formed on August 14,1863; and the enrollment of soldiers and their widows and orphans compiled in the late 1800s.

Activities at home and overseas during World War I are represented in the Elkhart County Historical Museum archives in personal papers and pamphlets. Among the collections are the personal papers and training materials of 1st Lieutenant Claude French, who entered the service on September 21,1917, and was an instructor at Field Artillery Central Officer's Training School. For a woman's perspective
and notes on medical aspects of the war, one should consult the diary and military papers of Maud Essig, Reserve Army Nurse Corps, who served in the American Expeditionary Forces in France in 1919. Also among the archives' World War I collections are the notes of the Elkhart County Council of Defense from June 23, 1918, to November 16, 1918. This committee of public officials and civic leaders was created to oversee various aspects of Elkhart County life during World War I, including the activities of conscientious objectors, campaigns to increase food production and preservation, and intervention in labor troubles. This collection also contains the list of ex-servicemen in Elkhart , compiled November 1,1920, from American Legion membership cards by the Elkhart Public Library.

Life at the front and at home during World War II can be reviewed in a number of primary sources ranging from war bulletins and information on the men and women from Elkhart County who served in the armed forces to the activities of the local Office of Price Administration, War Bond Drive, Civil Defense Council, and Air Raid Wardens. War production lists were compiled for a number of local companies, such as C. G. Conn, Ltd., Elkhart Lumber & Saw Mill Company, Railway Express Agency, and Barnes Heater Company. Many letters to friends and families have been preserved; these describe life overseas as well as at home. The James Ozanne collection, in particular, contains a number of letters from James Ozanne, Jr., initially stationed at Camp Forrest, Tennessee , to his family in Elkhart . Ozanne was later reported missing in action on November 29, 1942, shortly after being sent to the Pacific theater. This collection also documents his family's attempt to accept and understand the circumstances of his death through correspondence with his commanding officers and exchanges with other families who also lost their sons.

Other sources at the Elkhart County Historical Society cover the development of the medical profession from the early days of grinding and preparing herbs for sale as medicinals in the personal papers of Paul Herring, dated 1873; to physicians' licensing records, which include education and specialization from the turn of the century to the 1940s; to the records of local physician Mary Bartholamew. Views of alchemy and pharmacy are in the Hawk Drug Store's medicinal recipe books, dating from the early 1900s, and the Goshen Pharmacal Company inventory, taken around 1900 by representatives of the county government. The county's treatment of the mentally ill and incompetent can be studied in the Elkhart County Home records.

The local music industry for which Elkhart is famous is represented in pamphlets and papers from Buescher, Selmer, Pan-American, Martin, and C. G. Conn, Ltd. Included in these collections are drawings and specifications of various instruments, serial numbers, and sales manuals. Personal contracts, employee handbooks, and
other papers belonging to individuals working for these companies are part of these corporate holdings. The Greenleaf family has donated a number of scrapbooks, personal papers, and diaries dating from 1816 to 1985. Carl D. Greenleaf was the president of C. G. Conn, Ltd., from 1915 to 1949. The bulk of these materials center around his life in Elkhart and that of his daughter, Dorothy G. Boynton.

A wide variety of other businesses, from banks to general stores, buggy shops, smithies, and insurance agencies, are represented in the archives and range from the early days of Elkhart County to the present. One of the earliest cash books dates from February 8, 1854, in Cleveland Township and includes payments made on accounts such as eggs, butter, and pork. Even earlier business accounts are given in personal correspondence, such as a letter dated October 12,1839, from Jesse D. Vail of Benton to Hannah Vail of Union, Pennsylvania , in which he describes the local crops as being first rate, the money scarce, and business dull.

The Elkhart County Historical Society recently acquired the personal and professional papers of three generations of the James M. Dale family, who resided in Goshen from the 1870s until 1996. J. M. Dale owned a dry goods store in Goshen from the 1870s until the turn of the century. Among the items donated are a vast number of the cash and daily account books from this business. Dale's daughter, Cora Belle Dale, was a composer and painter of some repute at the turn of the century. Her personal letters and writings, as well as copies of her compositions for voice and piano published either under her name or her professional name Ame Traverse, are also in this collection. Cora Belle Dale was admitted to a mental hospital in the late 1910s. The letters she wrote to her family of her experiences there and the letters between her brother and the staff physicians at Longmont have been preserved.

The holdings of the Elkhart County Historical Society, unlike those in many local history archives, contain an almost even distribution of documents pertaining to the activities of women and men. In addition to the collections already mentioned, local women's organization records are available; included are those of the League of Woman Voters and World War II Mothers. There is, however, a dearth of information regarding the activities of black and Hispanic individuals in the county.

Until recently the focus of the society has been on collecting items and providing information for individuals interested in genealogical research. The archives' current goals include upgrading preservation techniques and broadening the accessibility of the collections for general researchers on all topics.

div.head: Book Reviews
Gene Stratton-Porter: Voice of the Limberlost. Produced by Ann Aldridge and Nancy Carlson, 1996. 56 minutes. (Distributed by Indiana University Press, Bloomington , Ind. $19.95.)
div.p: The recent film Gene Stratton-Porter: Voice of the Limberlost is further evidence of the perennial interest in the life and works of Gene Stratton-Porter. It is an attractive and comprehensive documentary that will be welcomed by readers and conservationists alike.

Beginning with Stratton-Porter's childhood on a farm near Geneva , Indiana, the film dramatizes her early interest in birds, following her through her growing commitment to the study of the Limberlost, to the publication of the nature novels that made her famous (and rich), to the move to California where she made movies of her novels, carried on new nature studies, and met an untimely death in a car accident. The narration by Tom Cochran is a model of clarity and objectivity.

One of the beauties of the film lies in the magnificent shots of the Limberlost Swamp, the close-ups of the birds and wild flowers, and the significant attention given to the residences Stratton-Porter built to accommodate her nature and photographic activities. Some of the pictures are from archival sources, but many are of the contemporary scene as well. Another strong point of the film is its expert interleaving of social, political, and business events and scenes with Stratton-Porter's story: the industrial activity reflected in the busy railroads and factories, the burgeoning oil and timber industries that spelled bad news for the Limberlost, the impact of World War I, the women's suffrage movement, the little Chautauquas that provided both learning and social activities. Life in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries comes alive in these related segments.

The focus, however, remains on Stratton-Porter and her conservation activities. Her major writings are given careful and illustrative attention demonstrating not only how she wove into her stories the nature she knew so well but also how she underscored the lives of her characters with her own active principles of hard work and integrity. In addition, her characters were engaged in understanding nature and preserving it against developers and industrialists.

The comments of Scott Sanders reflect the filmmakers' implied conviction that Stratton-Porter was an ecologist long before the name of the science had become a household word. The apt quotations from her own writings, extremely well read by Annette O'Toole, are proof of Stratton-Porter's early concern for the vital relation between organisms and their environment. The opening and closing pictures of the renewal of Limberlost Swamp and the restoration of wetlands in the area dramatize the vision that Stratton-Porter had many years earlier.

It is not hard to see why this film won an award of excellence from the Film Advisory Board. The filming itself, the story it tells of a strong-minded conservationist, and the weaving together of the strands of nature, literature, and conservation-all are admirably served in a short space.
div.byline: MARY E. GAITHER is professor emerita of English and comparative literature, Indiana University, Bloomington . She is the author of introductions to reprints of Gene Stratton-Porter's The Harvester and Laddie, both published by Indiana University Press.

div.head: Peopling Indiana: The Ethnic Experience. Edited by Robert M. Taylor, Jr., and Connie A. McBirney. ( Indianapolis : Indiana Historical Society, 1996. Pp. xiii, 703. Illustrations, notes, maps, tables, figures, appendices, index. $39.95.)
div.p:
In their preface to this volume, editors Robert M. Taylor, Jr., and Connie A. McBirney report that each contributor to Peopling Indiana was given a copy of They Chose Minnesota: A Survey of the State's Ethnic Groups (1981). In addition, they urged each writer to review the monumental Harvard
Encyclopedia of American Ethnic Groups (1980). Taylor and McBirney's selection of these top-drawer models yielded superb results. For the Indiana volume some thirty-four scholars supplied texts on thirty ethnic groups plus additional topics such as the overall ethnic history of the state and an appendix piece detailing ethnicity in what was once the Old Northwest. These articles are followed by tables and maps of the foreign born by ethnic group as a percentage of total population and ethnic group by county. Covering the decades from 1850 to 1990, these tables are arranged for easy access.

Writing in the Journal of Ethnic History some years after the conclusion of the Minnesota project, Carleton Qualey, initiator of They Chose Minnesota, noted that Minnesota was by popular myth but certainly not in reality the "Scandinavian" state. Minnesota was in the late 1800s and remained in the 1990 census overwhelmingly German , with over 2 million Germans compared to less than 1.5 million Norwegians, Swedes, Danes, Finns, and Icelanders taken together. In Indiana as well, even filiopietistic writers like Albert Faust, in his
German Element in the United States
(1909), had largely skipped over Indiana's Germans. Peopling Indiana illustrates that through all decades from early settlement to the present the state was always heavily German , and in 1990 those of German ethnicity totaled over 2 million in a state whose population was 5.5 million. Thus the article by Giles R. Hoyt on the Germans is especially important for its material on this largest of the ethnic groups; it is also impressively capped by charts and pictures. A minor criticism is that the map for origins in Germany is contemporary and therefore does not include much of the former Reich territory from which the immigrants before
LOUIS VOLLRATH GEOCERY AND MEAT MARKET, INDIANAPOLIS, 1905
Indiana Historical Society Library, Indianapolis (Neg. no. C3156). World War I arrived. A minority of Indiana's Germans were possibly Polish or speakers of other languages. This notation would also apply to many of the other maps.

Peopling Indiana is for everyone not just students of ethnicity. Indeed, nearly every entry includes the history of the region or nation from which the separate groups arrived; positions the emigrants in their religious, social, geographic, economic, and gender backgrounds; and repositions these new Americans who shaped Indiana's history. For example, in the chapter on Greek emigrants, the history of Greece is interwoven with an Orthodox, Ottoman, sometimes Moslem past, which in turn is intertwined with a discussion on the French vineyard diseases that created demand for Greek currants, a market that collapsed upon the recovery of viniculture in France and impelled thousands of male Greeks to emigrate to the United States for a better economic future. According to law and tradition, Greece bases citizenship on heredity from the father while the United States considers birth site the determining factor. Greece , then, claims double the Greek emigrants to America than does the United States . Many Greeks arrived from the greater Ottoman-Byzantine territories of the greater Balkan peninsula. As usual with all immigrant groups,
TWO YOUNG MEN ON THEIR WAY TO WORK WITH LUNCH BUCKETS IN HAND, GARY, INDIANA, 1908
Photograph courtesy Mary Leuca. the waxing and waning of political and cultural prominence at home was reflected in Greek communities of Indiana.

Equally rich are the chapters about the Lithuanians, Latvians, Estonians, Hispanics, Poles, and others. Folklorist Linda Degh's essay on the Hungarians is enhanced by her anthropological perspective. Monsignor Joseph Semancik, in his article on the Slovaks, reveals his affection for his people and their religion when he deals with the problem of place of origin, nationality, and ethnicity and the fact that many Slovaks were called Hunkies because they emigrated from the region that had belonged to the Austro-Hungarian empire. A comparable warmth for his subject matter characterizes William W. Giffin's entry about the Irish, the second largest Indiana immigrant group. Ophelia Georgiev Roop and Lilia Georgiev Judson deserve similar praise for their data on Bulgarians and Macedonians.

Americans who want to understand themselves must first understand the European complexities that impelled emigration to the United States . Readers are therefore urged not merely to sample Peopling Indiana but to read it all. The volume is truly a singular achievement.
div.byline:
LA VERN J. RIPPLEY specializes in German -American history in the German Department, St. Olaf College, Northfield, Minnesota . Two of his most recent works are
German -Bohemians: The Quiet Immigrants (1995) and Noble Women, Restless Men (1996), a history of his own extended family of immigrants from central Europe.

div.head: Two Sides to Everything: The Cultural Construction of Class Consciousness in Harlan County , Kentucky . By Shaunna L. Scott. ( Albany : State University of New York Press, 1995. Pp. xxvii, 259. Illustrations, tables, notes, references, indices. Clothbound, $54.50; paperbound, $17.95.)
div.p:
In a country in which working-class consciousness has been seen as episodic at best, if not largely absent, Harlan County , Kentucky , has been enshrined as the quintessential epicenter. There, according to labor lore, coal miners, confronted by adamantly antiunion employers, launched a series of heroic struggles over the course of the twentieth century. Its place in the popular imagination was secured, it seemed, by Barbara Kopple's Academy Award-winning documentary,
Harlan County U.S.A. (1977).

Shaunna L. Scott's carefully presented study, Two Sides to Everything, tells a much more complex story. Based on painstaking research, Scott's anthropological examination offers readers a solid foundation from which to explore the nature of class consciousness, both in the historical and the present setting. In the end, it is far more useful than any mere celebration of class struggle could be.

A daughter of the region herself, Scott uses her personal experiences and contacts in order to probe the evolution and transformation of working-class identity over several generations. Throughout both her research and her writing, Scott the scholar remains acutely sensitive to the promise and pitfalls of her insider/outsider status. In so doing, she not only opens windows into working-class experience but also into the challenges of conducting contemporary research.

As her title suggests, Scott finds "two sides to everything." While Harlan County 's miners and their families are aware of the differences between their experiences and status and those of their employers, their ideological constructions revolve more around their regional identities and the threat they sense from outside economic and political interests. That these outside interests include United Mine Workers officials as well as multinational conglomerates further complicates the narrative. The miners draw upon kinship, community, and religion to build their sense of class; but these factors also provide the
material for a regional identity that excludes class altogether and draws them into a series of alliances and coalitions with local middle-class elements, including the owners of small, nonunion mines.

Scott carefully traces these dynamics over a half century punctuated by both strikes and ventures into labor-management partnerships. She draws on historical research and oral history interviews with men and women from three generations to piece together this fascinating story, punctuating it with an analysis drawn from recent work in several scholarly disciplines. But it is her closing treatment of the effort to construct a Miners Memorial in the mid-1980s that draws her account together in a compelling fashion. There, she explains the inner workings of a coalition that includes the Jaycees, veteran union miners, and diverse community members, a coalition that sought to depoliticize the experiences of miners in order to make them acceptable. While this project failed at first even in its own rather convoluted terms, it ultimately resulted in a monument which seemed to satisfy all of those involved. That Scott does not hide her surprise but uses it constructively to make sense out of this complex tale suggests the quality of this study.

Although Scott herself notes that she did not accord enough attention to the dynamics of race and gender in her research and her analysis, she has written a strong and valuable book. Students of class consciousness-not just in Harlan County but in Indiana and elsewhere-would be well advised to read Two Sides to Everything. Their efforts will be rewarded.
div.byline: PETER RACHLEFF is professor of history, Macalester College, St. Paul, Minnesota . He is a labor historian with a particular interest in race and ethnicity. His most recent publication is "Wall-to-Wall Unionism: The Independent Union of All Workers, 1933–1937," in "We Are All Leaders": The Alternative Unionism of the Early 1930s, ed. Staughton Lynd (1996).

div.head: How the West Was Lost: The Transformation of Kentucky from Daniel Boone to Henry Clay. By Stephen Aron. ( Baltimore : Johns Hopkins University Press, 1996. Pp. xi, 285. Illustrations, maps, tables, notes, index. $29.95.)
div.p:
In the historiography of the trans-Appalachian West, the basic law of physics applies: for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. Over a century ago Theodore Roosevelt and Frederick Jackson Turner wrote histories narrating (and celebrating) the achievements of pioneer emigrants to the Ohio and Mississippi valley frontiers. A generation later they were countered by less "triumphalist" Depression-era scholars (most notably Turner's student Thomas Perkins Abernethy) who were, in turn, countered by post-World War II scholars such as R. Carlyle Buley and Thomas D. Clark. Reaction to this neo-Turnerian positivism began in the late 1960s and
has now reached high tide. Thus, a hundred years after Roosevelt wrote The Winning of the West Stephen Aron has written How the West Was Lost.

Aron's book focuses exclusively on the Bluegrass and Green River regions of Kentucky but makes generalizations that are to apply to all of the trans-Appalachian (and, in some cases, trans- Mississippi ) West. Beginning with a thorough discussion of the interrelationship and cross-acculturation of native people and the long hunters (represented by Boone), Aron proceeds systematically through initial settlement, land distribution, customary vis-a-vis formal legal rights, agriculture, slavery, and the evolution of the market-driven Kentucky of Henry Clay. Aron's cliometrics document the fact that, in these two parts of Kentucky , rich people held more land than poor people, many of whom held no land at all. Unequal land distribution is only one of Aron's many criticisms of early Kentucky . "This is a book about possibilities lost," writes Aron, a book which "seeks to explain what did not happen" in frontier Kentucky . Aron's list of "what did not happen" includes:
the preservation of indigenous fauna and flora, the coalescence or at least continued coexistence of Ohio Indian and backcountry hunters, the protection of pioneer homesteading privileges, the equal distribution or redistribution of land, the perpetuation of customary common rights, the democratization of legal and political systems, the abolition of slavery, the confederation of free and unfree laborers, the implementation of an agrarian political economy, the arrival of the millennium (pp. 3–4).
How the West Was Lost is an engagingly written book based on a thorough working of regional archives and secondary books and periodical literature published since the late 1960s. The text is accompanied by extensive quantified data and a map.

Aron has gained a reputation as a critic of the "new" western historians' inattention to the trans-Appalachian West, and he is certainly correct in his broader geographical definition of frontier history. Most of Aron's critique of the new western history, however, consists of a minor disagreement over the "site" of victimization. The new western historians argue that only the trans- Mississippi West should be the focus of their study of race, class, gender, and environment. Aron argues that the trans-Appalachian West should also be included in the study of race, class, gender, and environment. It is a sign of the state of contemporary western history scholarship (and all contemporary historical scholarship for that matter) that scholars are somehow to construe a disagreement over where to apply this tired, politically correct viewpoint as evidence of lively scholarly debate.

Absent from Aron's presentist analysis is a discussion of important facets of Kentucky culture and the many benefits westerners accrued from the industrial revolution, capitalism, and republican political institutions. These include a rapidly increasing standard of living, a land distribution system more egalitarian than anywhere else on earth, expanded suffrage, increased literacy, and the development
of a coarse, vibrant folk culture. Turner, Roosevelt, and Clark pointed to, and overemphasized, these positive frontier characteristics. They did not stress the class strife documented (sixty-seven years ago) by Abernethy and now again by Aron. After one hundred years both camps have made their points again and again. In light of the emerging reaction to the neo-Marxist scholarship of the past generation, historians of the Ohio and Mississippi valleys would do well to return to two evenhanded syntheses. Malcolm J. Rohrbough's The Trans-Appalachian West (1978) and Richard Bartlett's The New Country (1974) provide a sound foundation for what this reviewer hopes will be, in the next century, a less polemical interpretation of the West of Daniel Boone and Henry Clay.

All specialists should read this well-written and provocative book. It should appear in graduate and undergraduate libraries in the trans-Appalachian West and in graduate libraries elsewhere. It complements, but does not replace, the work of Turner, Roosevelt, Abernethy, Buley, Clark, and other scholars who have described how the West was "won" and "lost."
div.byline:
MICHAEL ALLEN is associate professor of history, University of Washington , Tacoma. His books include Western Rivermen, 1763–1861:
Ohio and Mississippi Boatmen and the Myth of the Alligator Horse (1990). Allen is currently working on Rodeo Cowboys in the North American Imagination: The History of A Contemporary Ancestor in Popular Culture.

div.head: Before Big Blue: Sports at the University of Kentucky , 1880–1940. By Gregory Kent Stanley. ( Lexington : University Press of Kentucky , 1996. Pp. xii, 192. Illustrations, tables, notes, bibliography, index. $19.95.)
div.p: A president of a midwestern university once said that he was attempting to build a university that the football team could be proud of. Gregory Kent Stanley, in his study of sports at the University of Kentucky down to 1940, writes of presidents simultaneously trying to create a good university and a manageable sports program, the athletic impulse, especially football, sometimes hindering the academic mission.

Using newspapers of Lexington and university records, Stanley views the sports program through the presidencies of three men. All had to deal with problems in its governance. James Patterson, first president of the university (1869–1910), disliked football and wished to ban it, believing that it deprived students of time necessary to their studies. The student athletic association, which controlled football, frustrated his attempt in 1893 to prohibit its play. He did manage to give the faculty jurisdiction over the association.

In the hands of the students the football program limped along at the turn of the century. Its financial health was too dependent on the annual Thanksgiving Day game with Transylvania University,
the other university in Lexington . The competition with Transylvania engendered charges and countercharges about the use of ineligible players, often "ringers."

The successor to Patterson, Henry Barker (1910–1917), was more sympathetic to the game. He created the position of athletic director; the director, faculty, students, and alumni constituted an athletic council controlling sports. More importantly, the director and his assistant coaches received faculty salaries, and the assistant football coaches served as coaches for minor sports such as track and men's and women's basketball. Marring Barker's administration was a scandalous episode involving a former assistant football coach accused of setting fire to the office of a faculty member on the athletic council who had become "harsh" on issues of eligibility.

Succeeding Barker was Frank McVey (1917–1940). Under McVey the university, with the help of alumni, constructed a football stadium and basketball gymnasium.
